{{context|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox Court Case | name = Oršuš and Others v. Croatia | court = [[European Court of Human Rights]] | image = | imagesize = | caption = | full name = | date decided = 16 March 2010 | citations = | transcripts = | judges = [[Jean-Paul Costa]], [[Nicolas Bratza]], [[Françoise Tulkens]], [[Josep Casadevall]], [[Karel Jungwiert]], [[Nina Vajić]], [[Anatoly Kovler]], [[Elisabeth Steiner]], [[Alvina Gyulumyan]], [[Renate Jaeger]], [[Egbert Myjer]], David Thór Björgvinsson, [[Ineta Ziemele]], Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre, Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska, [[Işıl Karakaş]], Nebojša Vučinić | prior actions = CC of Croatia judgment in favour of government; ECtHR Chamber judgment in favour of applicants on article 6, in favour of government on article 14 and P1-2 | subsequent actions = | opinions = '''Majority:''' Costa, Bratza, Tulkens, Casadevall, Steiner, Björgvinsson, Ziemele, Trajkovska, Karakaş
'''Joint partial dissent:''' Jungwiert, Vajić, Kovler, Gyulumyan, Jaeger, Myjer, Berro-Lefèvre, Vučinić | keywords = Right to education, language, discrimination }} '''''Oršuš and Others v. Croatia''''' (15766/03) was a case heard before the European Court of Human Rights, concerning activities of [[Romani people|Roma]]-only classes in some schools of Croatia, which were held legal by the [[Constitutional Court of Croatia]] in 2007 by a decision no. U-III-3138/2002.[http://sljeme.usud.hr/usud/prakswen.nsf/Ustav/C12570D30061CE53C125727B0038B838?OpenDocument Constitutional Court decision] ==Chamber judgment== On 17 July 2008, the Chamber of Court's First Section found unanimously both that there had been a violation of Article 6 of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] on account of the excessive length of the proceedings, and that there had not been a violation of Article 2 of Protocol No. 1 (right to education) taken alone or in conjunction with Article 14 of the Convention (ban of discrimination).[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=837978&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 Chamber judgment] ==Grand Chamber judgment== On 16 March 2010, the court delivered the judgment, finding a violation of Article 6, unanimously, and a violation of Article 14 of ECHR read in conjunction with Article 2 of Protocol No. 1, by nine votes to eight. The majority has considered that ''the schooling arrangements for Roma children were not sufficiently attended by safeguards that would ensure that, in the exercise of its margin of appreciation in the education sphere, the State had sufficient regard to their special needs as members of a disadvantaged group'' and ''as a result of the arrangements the applicants were placed in separate classes where an adapted curriculum was followed, though its exact content remains unclear. Owing to the lack of transparency and clear criteria as regards transfer to mixed classes, the applicants stayed in Roma-only classes for substantial periods of time, sometimes even during their entire primary schooling'' (Para. 182). Judges Jungwiert, [[Nina Vajić|Vajić]], Kovler, [[Alvina Gyulumyan|Gyulumyan]], [[Renate Jaeger|Jaeger]], [[Egbert Myjer|Myjer]], Berro-Lefèvre and Vučinić have filed a joint partly dissenting opinion, finding no violation of Articles 14 and P1-2. They referred to interests of Croatian-speaking children (Para. 9) and right of minority to preserve diversity (para. 17), pointing that: *applicants agreed they lacked the required level of language proficiency (Para. 4), *the Roma-only classes were not established as a rule (Para. 6), *the slow linguistic development and progress in the applicants' case was to a large degree due to their very poor school attendance (Para. 7), *''pupils who at times or during their entire primary education attend Roma-only classes and successfully complete final grade also receive the same standard final certificate which in no way indicates that they attended some special, separate classes'' (para. 11).[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=864619&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 Grand Chamber judgment] ==Aftermath== According to [[European Roma Rights Centre|ERRC]] evaluation after a visit to Croatia in June 2010, "The situation in the schools remains the same; the majority of Romani children continue to attend Roma-only classes. The ERRC even identified one more school in the village of [[Podturen]] where Romani children are attending Roma-only classes. The situation for applicants in the Oršuš case themselves is little improved and they have been reportedly threatened with the possibility of having their social benefits cut because of their damages award. The only positive development was an initiative coming from the directors of the primary schools at the heart of the case which asked Medjimurje county authorities and the Ministry of Education to introduce three-year, free of charge pre-school programmes for Romani children to help these children to overcome language barriers before beginning their primary education".Memedov I. [http://www.errc.org/cikk.php?page=10&cikk=3613 European Court Denounces Segregated Education Again: Oršuš and Others v Croatia] Roma Rights 1, 2010: Implementation of Judgments In March, 2011, [[Amnesty International]] has filed a submission to the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe concerning implementation of the judgment, where it found several shortcomings.[https://wcd.coe.int/wcd/com.instranet.InstraServlet?command=com.instranet.CmdBlobGet&InstranetImage=1806268&SecMode=1&DocId=1717772&Usage=2 submission to the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe on Oršuš and Others v. Croatia] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *Reaction to the 2008 judgment: **[http://echrblog.blogspot.com/2008/07/separate-but-still-equal.html Separate, But Still Equal] Buyse, Antoine. Utrecht University *Reaction to 2010 judgment: **[http://www.harvardilj.org/2010/03/ecthr-rules-croatian-school-segregation-discriminatory/ ECtHR Rules Croatian School Segregation Discriminatory] **[http://echrblog.blogspot.com/2010/03/roma-education-grand-chamber-judgment.html Roma Education Grand Chamber Judgment in Orsus] Buyse, Antoine. Utrecht University **[https://wcd.coe.int/wcd/com.instranet.InstraServlet?command=com.instranet.CmdBlobGet&InstranetImage=1768705&SecMode=1&DocId=1689178&Usage=2 Communication from Croatia on the implementation of the judgment] {{DEFAULTSORT:Orsus And Others V. Croatia}} [[Category:2010 in case law]] [[Category:2010 in Croatia]] [[Category:Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights]] [[Category:Article 14 of the European Convention on Human Rights]] [[Category:Article 2 of Protocol No. 1 of the European Convention on Human Rights]] [[Category:Education in Croatia]] [[Category:Romani in Croatia]] [[Category:European Court of Human Rights cases involving Croatia]] [[Category:European Court of Human Rights cases decided by the Grand Chamber]] [[Category:Minority schools]] [[Category:Romani rights]] [[Category:2010 in education]]

{{multiple issues| {{relevance inline|date=June 2016}} {{notability|Web|date=June 2016}} }} {{Infobox Website | name = Praxis | logo = Praxis,_break_the_mold_logo,_vertical.jpg | logo_size = 200px | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{url|http://www.discoverpraxis.com}} | commercial = Yes | type = [[Education]] | language = English | registration = | owner = Isaac Morehouse | key people = 2013 | alexa = | current status = Active }}
'''Praxis''' is a for-profit [[apprenticeship]] program in the United States. It places young people at paid positions with [[Startup company|startup companies]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Magill|first1=Derek|title=The UM Dropout Whose Startup Wants to Get You Your Dream Job Without a College Degree|url=http://www.michiganreview.com/derek-magill-praxis/|accessdate=26 August 2016|publisher=The Michigan Review|date=October 22, 2015}}</ref> Participants in the program are not required to have a college degree.<ref name="The Freeman">[http://www.fee.org/the_freeman/detail/is-there-a-viable-alternative-to-college#ixzz2ZOwQPm4f The Freeman] "Is There a Viable Alternative to College?" by Jeffrey Tucker, July 13, 2013</ref><ref name="Capitol Confidential">[http://www.michigancapitolconfidential.com/18887 Capitol Confidential] ''As Higher Education Bubble Accelerates, Alternative Emerge'' By Jarrett Skorup, July 17, 2013</ref><ref name="John William Pope Center for Higher Education Policy">[http://www.popecenter.org/commentaries/article.html?id=2907#.U8VVSY1dVV0 John William Pope Center for Higher Education Policy] "Boot Camp for Professional Careers" By Anders Edwardsson and Jay Schalin, September 27, 2013</ref> Praxis was founded by Isaac Morehouse in 2013.<ref name="realclear">[https://soundcloud.com/realclearradiohour/breaking-the-mold-a-practical Real Clear Radio Hour] ''Breaking the Mold-A Practical Alternative to College''</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Boucher|first1=Stephen|title="Companies don't care about degrees": As credentials lose their value, state subsidized university makes no sense|url=http://www.therebel.media/_companies_don_t_care_about_degrees|accessdate=26 August 2016|publisher=The Rebel|date=December 2, 2015}}</ref>
==Background== After interacting with businesspeople and students while working for an libertarian nonprofit, Praxis founder Isaac Morehouse noticed a skills gap between recently graduated college students and employers.<ref name="fifitk">[http://fionatk.podomatic.com/entry/2013-08-29T00_23_51-07_00 Conversations with FiFi and T.K.] ''Don't Go To College''</ref> Having been [[homeschooling|homeschooled]] himself and then exposed to a [[university]]-education, Morehouse noticed the disparity in skills taught and skills demanded by the professional world, as well as the frustration faced by students who expected a job upon graduation.<ref name=fifitk /> This led Morehouse to believe that most of the perceived value of a [[college degree]] comes from its value as a [[signaling (economics)|signaling mechanism]], showing employers that a candidate is superior to those without the signal. Employers told Morehouse that a lack of [[work experience]] was the primary reason they did not hire candidates with college degrees.<ref name=realclear /> Morehouse founded Praxis in 2013 as an alternative signal for employers and students, combining traditional educational components with [[work experience]].<ref name=fifitk />
==Description== Praxis places participants with business partners to work 30 hours per week as an employee (as opposed to a traditional [[internship|intern]]).<ref name="alisterpaine">[http://alisterpaine.com/2014/07/14/7-questions-with-the-guy-whos-disrupting-education/ Alister & Paine] ''Seven Questions with the Guy Who's Disrupting Education''</ref> Participants then complete 10 hours per week's worth of coursework designed by professors contracted with Praxis. The academic and non-academic subjects in the curriculum is designed to instill a level of [[entrepreneurship|entrepreneurial]] thinking in the participants, and to challenge them to think broadly about complex questions.<ref name="Praxis Blog">[http://blog.discoverpraxis.com/2013/11/07/is-a-liberal-arts-education-valuable/ Praxis Blog] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140729022718/http://blog.discoverpraxis.com/2013/11/07/is-a-liberal-arts-education-valuable/ |date=2014-07-29 }} ''Is A Liberal Arts Education Valuable?'' By Isaac Morehouse, November 7, 2013</ref> The combination of hands-on [[work experience]], [[technical education]] in the curriculum, and a [[liberal arts]] education is designed to train participants to work practically and to be [[wikt:analytic|analytic]] thinkers.<ref name="Praxis Blog 2">[http://blog.discoverpraxis.com/2013/09/02/is-praxis-only-for-entrepreneurs/ Praxis Blog] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140729064239/http://blog.discoverpraxis.com/2013/09/02/is-praxis-only-for-entrepreneurs/ |date=2014-07-29 }} ''Is Praxis Only For Entrepreneurs?''</ref>
Praxis also features [[resume]] and writing workshops, [[public speaking]] seminars, professional networking opportunities and a variety of [[professional development]] projects, both within the business partner context and within the broader scope of the program. Motivated by the belief that college costs are disproportionately high relative to the payoff of a degree, Morehouse designed the program to give participants "the best of a college education and [[reality|real-world]] [[work experience]]."<ref name="YouTube">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lc4h_FJkoZY YouTube] ''Praxis: A Real World Education''</ref>
The program is additionally structured as to provide low-cost, high-quality labor to small businesses and [[startup company|startups]].<ref name="Praxis">[http://www.discoverpraxis.com/business Praxis] ''Praxis for Business''</ref>
==Curriculum== The Praxis curriculum covers economics, history, entrepreneurship, and technology.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Soave|first1=Robby|title=As college costs increase, alternatives arise|url=http://dailycaller.com/2013/07/03/as-college-costs-increase-alternatives-arise/|accessdate=26 August 2016|publisher=The Daily Caller|date=July 3, 2013}}</ref>
The curriculum includes an additional portfolio project and hard skills module, which includes [[resume]] writing skills, writing development, [[interview]] skills, and [[public speaking]] skills.
Each subject in the Praxis curriculum is designed to prepare participants to be [[entrepreneurship|entrepreneurs]]. A notable feature of the Praxis curriculum is that participants are encouraged to engage directly with the material, and to challenge material they find superfluous, and replace it with similar material deemed more useful by participants.

Situated at the Pradarsani Marg [[Kathmandu]], [[Nepal]], ''Ratna Rajya Lakshmi Campus''', popularly known as RR Campus, is a constituent college of [[Tribhuvan University]] (TU). It is also the largest college for the Humanities and Social sciences of the nation. It provides the graduate and master degree level programs in morning, day and night shift classes. The college was named after then [[Queen Ratna of Nepal|Queen Ratna Rajya Lakshmi Devi Shah]], second wife of then [[Mahendra of Nepal|King Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev]].
'''Courses:'''
Ratna Rajya Lakshmi Campus offers different types of undergraduate and graduate level courses with recognition from Tribhuvan University:
Bachelor of Arts-BA
MA English
MA Nepali
MA Population Studies
MA in Journalism and Mass Communication
MA in Sociology
Master of Arts (MA) in Economics
